keyTakeAways: A steel cable used in the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed to meet the operational specifications set by CARRIS, the funicular’s operator.
The cable was not certified to carry people and was found to have serious structural and safety deficiencies.
Maintenance tasks were incorrectly marked as completed, and the maintenance plan was falsely recorded as compliant and accepted by the operator.
The crash occurred when the cable snapped shortly after the funicular cars began their journey on Calçada da Glória, resulting in a derailment and injuries or fatalities.
Eyewitnesses reported that one of the cars derailed and careened down the street, hitting a building and producing a loud bang and brown smoke.

The Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) conducted an interim investigation and found serious failures in the cable, maintenance, and braking systems.
The preliminary findings are not conclusive; the final report is expected to be released next year.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A preliminary investigation by Portugal's Office for the Prevention and Investigation of Accidents in Civil Aviation and Rail (GPIAAF) found that a steel cable used in the Glória funicular in Lisbon failed to meet the safety specifications set by its operator, CARRIS. The cable snapped shortly after the funicular cars began their journey on Calçada da Glória, leading to a derailment, with at least 16 fatalities and multiple injuries. Eyewitnesses described the event as chaotic, with one man named Bruno reporting the car appearing out of control and producing a loud bang and brown smoke. Maintenance records were found to be falsified, with tasks marked as complete despite not being performed, and the maintenance plan falsely declared compliant. The interim findings are not conclusive, and a final report is expected next year.
title: Cable in deadly Portugal funicular crash failed to meet specifications, preliminary report finds
